intro: Annona, commonly known as the custard apple, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Annonaceae. It consists of about 130 species, many of which are native to the Americas, Africa, and Southeast Asia. The plants are typically shrubs or small trees, characterized by their simple, alternate leaves and showy, white or greenish-yellow flowers. The fruit, which is the most notable part of the plant, is usually a rough-skinned, tropical fruit with a sweet, creamy pulp. Annona species are valued for their edible fruits and have also been used in traditional medicine for various purposes.
